title: Episode 99 â€“ David Beasley, ED, UN World Food Programme, 2020 Nobel Peace Prize Recipient
subtitle: TRANSCRIPT
full_transcript:
[8.8s - 27.1s]: Welcome to the Y on Earth community podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry. And today we have a very special episode with David Beasley, the executive director of the United Nations World Food Program, which was the recipient of the 2020 Nobel Peace Prize.

[27.1s - 45.1s]: The World Food Program is at the heart of the convergence of several global challenges with COVID, the economic impacts, climate change, environmental degradation, and political instability in communities throughout the world.

[45.1s - 73.8s]: The World Food Program is often the first and last line of defense for millions of people on the verge of starvation. You'll hear from David about not only the work they're doing right now to deal with these immediate crises for millions of our brothers and sisters around the world, but also the work that they're doing globally to help restore ecosystems and regenerate the foundations upon which our communities depend.

[75.1s - 98.3s]: As executive director of the World Food Program, David Beasley continues his life's work bridging political, religious, and ethnic boundaries to champion economic development and education. At WFP, Mr. Beasley is putting to use four decades of leadership and communication skills to mobilize more financial support and public awareness for the global fight against hunger.

[98.3s - 126.4s]: These efforts were recognized this year when the Norwegian Nobel Committee awarded the World Food Program the 2020 Nobel Peace Prize. Before coming to WFP in 2017, Mr. Beasley spent a decade working with high profile leaders and on the ground program managers in more than 100 countries directing projects designed to foster peace, reconciliation, and economic progress.

[127.2s - 148.3s]: As governor of the US State of South Carolina from 1995 to 1999, Mr. Beasley guided the state during years of economic transformation, helping to reshape the state's economy into a healthy, diverse, and robust market. Mr. Beasley earned the John F. Kennedy Profile Encourage Award.

[149.1s - 160.7s]: He received his bachelor's degree from Clemson University and a doctor of jurisprudence degree from the University of South Carolina and taught at the Harvard University Kennedy School of Government.

[161.4s - 171.5s]: He was first elected to public office at the age of 21 as a member of the South Carolina House of Representatives. Without further ado, here's David Beasley.

[172.2s - 174.4s]: Director Beasley, welcome to the show.

[176.0s - 182.9s]: It's great to be with you. It's been quite a while and we got some really important and good things to talk about.

[183.6s - 198.9s]: Yeah, we sure do. And as the executive director of the World Food Program, you are, first of all, let me just say congratulations on receiving the Nobel Peace Prize just a couple of months ago.

[199.6s - 210.7s]: That's just a tremendous recognition of the work you and your team are already doing, but I think also it's going to help bring more awareness to the important issues you all are tackling.

[211.0s - 217.2s]: So congratulations. Can you tell us what is it like to get that phone call?

[218.2s - 222.5s]: Well, you don't get that phone call every day. I can just argue with that.

[223.4s - 235.0s]: If we had known that we were going to get it, we probably would have choreographed this really fancy setting with a suit and all these inspired words.

[235.0s - 243.6s]: As it was, I literally was in the middle of knees, and we were in a very tense situation. We were negotiating access.

[243.8s - 257.6s]: I'd just come back from the field where we're trying to get access in the area where I had al-Qaeda on one side and ISIS on the other side because these extremist groups use access as a weapon for recruitment by the private people of food.

[257.6s - 262.5s]: So it was a pretty intense discussion and all of a sudden somebody blessed into the room.

[262.9s - 264.7s]: And I'm like, what the heck?

[265.2s - 270.2s]: And this person said, Nobel Peace Prize. I was like, oh wow, who won it?

[270.7s - 276.8s]: They said, we did. You did. The World Blue Program did. And I was like, you got to be kidding me.

[277.3s - 280.8s]: Wow. I mean, it really was a surprise.

[280.8s - 288.3s]: And I think, you know, Aaron, as you were saying, it was two things I think the Nobel Peace Prize Committee was doing.

[288.7s - 300.8s]: The first, I think they were saying, hey, World Food Program, you're 20,000 women and men that are out there putting their lives on the line, lives at risk in war zones, conflict areas, natural disasters.

[301.0s - 306.2s]: Thank you for bringing peace and stability to many, many places around the world.

[306.2s - 310.8s]: So that was number one, you know, as a model for the, for others around the world.

[311.3s - 318.5s]: Number two, it, I think it was a call to action because I believe the Nobel Peace Prize Committee saw exactly what we were seeing.

[318.6s - 327.9s]: While 2020 was a tough year, 2021 is going to even be more difficult because of the COVID economic ripple effect, the supply chain disruption.

[327.9s - 344.8s]: And when I say supply chain disruption, that is a comprehensive comment because we're talking about port, port shuts down, border crossing shutdowns, export ban, seeds, fertilizers, all these things that are critical to many of the developing nations around the world.

[344.8s - 352.4s]: So we, in the World Food Program, our needs because of the ripple effect are double.

[352.9s - 360.5s]: The number of people that literally are marching to the Branker Starvation, I'm not talking about people that just go to bit hungry.

[361.1s - 363.4s]: I'm talking about people that are marching to starvation.

[363.4s - 369.7s]: That number spiked from 135 to 270 million people.

[370.0s - 372.4s]: So our needs, financial needs have doubled.

[372.8s - 375.2s]: And we can talk about this more in detail in a little bit.

[375.7s - 381.3s]: But 2021 is going to be a very, very difficult year.

[382.7s - 390.3s]: Let me just mention right there that for folks who would like to get even more information about the World Food Program, they can go to wfp.org.

[390.3s - 404.2s]: David, I'm wondering, are you sensing that the national leaderships of the member nations around the world understand the magnitude of the problems and risks?

[404.4s - 408.6s]: And are they responding in a way that you're encouraged is you in terms of resources?

[408.6s - 411.1s]: Well, in 2020 they did.

[411.5s - 429.6s]: And early on with COVID, a lot of the leaders were making decisions about COVID sort of in the vacuum, not understanding the ripple effect that it was taking and shutting down economies and particularly in light, very poor, undeveloped nations and urban areas when you shut down a city and have a lockdown.

[430.2s - 439.0s]: It's not like in the United States, for example, the people, if you have a lockdown for two weeks, three weeks, you got food in your pantry for two to three weeks.

[439.7s - 443.3s]: You might not like what you eat on the third week, but you go be okay.

[444.0s - 448.2s]: Well, where we are, it's hand to mouth every day. There's not a pantry full of food.

[448.3s - 452.2s]: So if you have a lockdown, you've got to have a safety net program in place.

[452.2s - 465.0s]: And so what I did, and if I recall correctly, it was about two weeks before I was speaking to the United Nations Security Council about the travesty that we were looking at.

[465.7s - 472.0s]: And Tony Blair called me and he said, David, you are more places around the world than about anybody.

[472.0s - 478.5s]: What are you seeing out there? And I said, Tony, I'm afraid if we're not careful, the cure is going to be worse than the disease.

[478.5s - 485.2s]: And so we've got to really balance the health pandemic, COVID pandemic, with a health with a hunger pandemic.

[485.4s - 488.1s]: If we don't, it will have catastrophic consequences.

[488.5s - 492.3s]: And so I broke it down with Tony for about a half a dozen countries.

[492.7s - 496.1s]: What we were seeing over the next four to five quarters.

[496.8s - 501.6s]: And the economic dynamics in each of the countries and how it has a different effect.

[502.1s - 507.3s]: And Tony was like, oh my gosh, you've got to tell the world what you're seeing.

[507.3s - 513.6s]: And so I did. I went to the Security Council, gave them the very grave reality, what we were facing.

[514.0s - 517.4s]: And the world leaders stepped up in a very significant way.

[517.7s - 522.4s]: You had economic stimulus packages about $19 trillion in the year 2020.

[523.0s - 527.1s]: But there was debt deferral for low-income countries that would take their debt payment.

[527.2s - 533.4s]: Instead of sending it to the financial institutions, they used that for safety net programs to get through 2020.

[533.4s - 538.4s]: And I could go on and on and on and all the good things that were done.

[538.6s - 545.6s]: Because what happened in 2020, we didn't have famine, we didn't have destabilization, and we didn't have mass migration.

[545.6s - 548.5s]: Because we received the funds that we needed.

[548.8s - 552.7s]: We assisted about 100 million people in 2020.

[552.7s - 562.6s]: But we were hoping that COVID would be in our rearview mirror in the 2021 would be a lighter path forward.

[563.0s - 565.1s]: Unfortunately, that's not the case.

[565.5s - 569.1s]: So we don't have all the money available for 2020 for 2021.

[569.6s - 575.0s]: And now the needs are double. So here's what we're looking at with 270 million people.

[575.0s - 588.6s]: If we don't receive sufficient funds to address the most significant concerns, we will have mass famines, destabilization of nations, and mass migration.

[589.3s - 599.7s]: Now, if we don't do the things that we need to do, it's going to cost a thousand times more than getting on the front end and doing it right.

[599.7s - 607.9s]: Now, I've been talking to the leaders all day to day over the last few months, you're going to have to prioritize your limited funding.

[608.4s - 610.8s]: You can't say yet to everything in 2021.

[611.3s - 615.8s]: And so I use the analogy, it's like the Titanic head and toward icebergs.

[616.0s - 618.6s]: You've got a broken piece of tile in the bathroom.

[619.0s - 624.0s]: You've got a little bit of wine stain on the carpet and a broken wine glass in the bar.

[624.0s - 626.5s]: But you've got three icebergs ahead of you.

[627.1s - 630.6s]: Which one are you going to focus on? The icebergs are the small things.

[630.6s - 636.0s]: I said, the icebergs are famine, destabilization, and mass migration.

[636.0s - 644.9s]: Because if we don't, we'll have war, conflict, and that is a thousand times more impact than not doing so.

[644.9s - 649.2s]: So I haven't had a leader yet, say they want to back down.

[649.4s - 651.2s]: They understand it, they get it.

[651.4s - 653.3s]: But the needs are so big.

[654.6s - 658.2s]: We can't expect the governments alone to pick up the tab.

[658.3s - 660.8s]: So that's why I'm now calling on the world's billionaires.

[661.4s - 670.5s]: Because last year 2020, the world's wealthiest people, the billionaires, increase their net worth.

[670.5s - 678.1s]: Net worth increase now by $5.2 billion per day per day for 2020.

[678.6s - 684.7s]: And all I'm asking is to give me one day's worth of your net worth increase to avert famine.

[684.9s - 688.2s]: I need five billion just to avert famine.

[688.7s - 696.8s]: If I get that, then with my traditional government support and private safety support, then we should really have...

[696.8s - 700.0s]: It will still be a tough 2021, but we'll get through it.

[700.1s - 701.6s]: That's sort of where we are now, Eric.

[703.0s - 713.3s]: Well, David, it's tremendous hearing from the central purview that you have the degree of systemic risk we're facing right now.

[713.4s - 723.4s]: And I would argue that probably a whole lot of us in the general public aren't quite aware of just how much more difficult challenging it.

[723.4s - 728.0s]: And really devastating things could get in relatively short order here.

[728.4s - 736.8s]: Well, you know, and this is what I've been saying, because when you turn on the television the last four years, I mean, what was 90% of the news?

[737.0s - 738.7s]: It was Trump, Trump, Trump, Trump.

[738.8s - 742.2s]: Whether you loved or hated Trump or Brexit, Brexit, Brexit, Brexit.

[742.6s - 751.6s]: And people were not getting the information about destabilization and hurricanes and natural disasters, climate extremes, et cetera, et cetera, around the world.

[751.6s - 756.6s]: And we're out there all hands on deck, you know, every single day dealing with this.

[757.2s - 764.2s]: And so we see the reality and we see what's taking place over a longer-stained time period, you know, like on climate extremes.

[764.4s - 767.2s]: I've had some people say, well, I don't know about whether the climate's changing.

[767.2s - 781.6s]: And I said, look, you can debate all day long what's causing it to change, but I can tell you what you can't debate, because I'm out there first hand with my people seeing it what is happening in the Sahel and the world.

[781.6s - 790.7s]: In Southern Africa, Asia, where the climate is truly changing from more droughts, more flash floods, more this, more of that.

[791.1s - 798.1s]: And, you know, the poor people we're talking about in many of these places, they can't wait on a global solution.

[798.7s - 802.8s]: They got to survive the next year, because they've got to feed their children.

[803.0s - 805.8s]: They got to eat. They can't, you know, just jump in a car and drive somewhere.

[806.4s - 815.7s]: I mean, they got to survive them. And I think, listen, you and I talk about some of the things that we're doing on regenerating and rehabilitating the lands and the soils.

[816.4s - 827.5s]: Yeah, yeah. I'd love to hear that because I, you know, one of the things that strikes me, David, and, you know, even I met a few years back at a piece in reconciliation summit in Kosovo.

[827.5s - 836.5s]: And we've been looking at different aspects of these issues that are all entwined in a very complex global community and global situation.

[837.2s - 853.7s]: And it seems to me that especially given the potential degree of immediate crisis we're facing, and also knowing that a huge part of our solutions set going forward requires ecosystem and soil regeneration and restoration.

[853.7s - 858.9s]: And that's part of how we're going to stabilize some of these very vulnerable regions in the world.

[858.9s - 873.3s]: I'm curious to hear how you all at the World's Food Program are thinking about how to both tackle the immediate crises and potential crises and also help with the long term stabilization.

[874.2s - 885.5s]: You know, unfortunately, because we're facing so many fires this year, it's like put out the fires, put out the fires, you'll be like, you know, you're one of your children comes in and say, Dad, I want to talk about my new cow.

[885.6s - 890.5s]: And I'm like, you know, I like to talk about that, but I got four house fires right now. Let's just talk about that later.

[890.5s - 901.5s]: But on the long term perspective, if we don't deal with the issue that you were just raising, we're going to have calamity decades ahead of us.

[901.6s - 906.0s]: The population of the world is continuing to go up, of course, we're at 7.7 billion.

[906.5s - 913.8s]: We've done a lot of extraordinary successful things around the world in the last couple of hundred years, sharing more wealth and people getting more food.

[913.8s - 918.5s]: But it's not sustainable in the way we're going. So what can we do?

[919.4s - 935.5s]: You know, particularly in some of the areas that we are in, let's take Niger, Mali, Burkina Faso, the Sahel, you know, as the Sahara is moving down about a kilometer per year because of the lack of rain, etc., etc.

[936.3s - 946.0s]: And so in areas like this, when our old traditional approach was just bringing food and support people, well, you know, that's not changing anything.

[946.5s - 956.2s]: So we began working with the beneficiaries and let me say this, I hadn't found the beneficiary yet that said, I want to do nothing and sit around just get your food.

[956.5s - 964.4s]: I haven't met that person yet. They want to be independent. They want to be resilient. They want to be sustainable without outside support.

[964.4s - 976.4s]: And so we now come in and say, hey, we've got the food. We go work with you. And sometimes it may be a task. It depends on the modality that we need the most strategic and what reason.

[976.9s - 987.3s]: And so let's rehabilitate the land. And so we will do an area is like, you know, if you do pull up photos in the Sahel, I mean, it's pretty tough place.

[987.3s - 1004.6s]: If you go to these places, you're like, how in the world can you survive? Well, we do basic, I mean rudimentary basic agricultural practices of training and teaching half moon, side projects where we capture the limited water that comes.

[1005.2s - 1015.7s]: And so you don't have the flash flooding, capture the water, grows enough crops to survive. Now, we, I say we, I mean, I've been a fisheries.

[1015.7s - 1034.1s]: In the last four or five years of rehabilitated 3.5 million acres of land, 70, let's say 73, 75,000 kilometers of feeder roads for marketplace.

[1035.2s - 1049.2s]: It's hard to understand that in the Western community, but in a lot of these places, there aren't roads, you know, they're just not. And then I think 53,000 holding ponds, water reservoirs, wells.

[1049.8s - 1059.4s]: And our beneficiaries love it because they're out there. I had this one woman. She said, Mr. Beasley, this is a Nigerian. She said, she was standing on this hill and she stood with so much pride.

[1059.4s - 1074.5s]: She said, before we were dependent on you 100%. Now we've rehabilitated this land. I own five acres. I'm now not only feeding my family, I'm feeding my village. I'm buying five more acres and I'm going to sell to the marketplace.

[1074.5s - 1086.5s]: And it was just remarkable using just a basic of agricultural practices of taking the land and what she had to survive for her family and her children.

[1086.6s - 1103.2s]: Now, it's amazing that these are the people that pay the price for carbon consumption. And there was this doing more to rehabilitate and regenerate lands around the world. That's really kind of extraordinary. I'm so proud of them.

[1103.2s - 1117.4s]: And that's just some ideas of some of the things we do a lot of hydroponics on different places around the world. We're testing a lot of things. And of course, that's in the most difficult places on earth, like in Algeria and places where it's very dry.

[1117.6s - 1131.3s]: Now, hydroponics has a lot as you know, opportunities in urban areas and things like that. And we do a lot of also of artificial intelligence and hydro blockchain technology satellite imagery.

[1131.3s - 1153.3s]: We're doing a lot of different things, a lot of different patterns, but we also do a lot of composting. I was just in knee, I think it was knee share of bikina fossa where we've got women doing composting and not just for their village, but they're now selling that throughout the land from composting and a lot of things like that. But anyway, throw it back to you, Aaron.

[1153.3s - 1183.3s]: That's great to hear, David. And obviously all tools and technologies need to be deployed in smart manners here given the challenges that we're facing. And one of the things that has struck me over the last few years in the research that we've been doing at the wider community is that a 10% increase in soil carbon worldwide is equivalent to sequestering all of the fossil carbon we've released since the beginning of the year.

[1183.3s - 1203.2s]: And so it's the beginning of the industrial revolution. And you know, folks like John Lou, one of our recent guests, the founder of ecosystem restoration camps, who was very close to the project there at the Los Plateau in China, where they literally restored hundreds of thousands of acres of desert and brought hundreds of thousands of people out of extreme poverty.

[1203.2s - 1222.0s]: There's a way here we can not only help increase food security and sustainable economic development for communities in a lot of marginalized regions, but also restore the green fertility of the planet and stabilize the climate.

[1222.0s - 1242.7s]: And I'm struck that in North Africa, Middle East, you know, these are some of the most desertified and challenging places in the world. And our tradition tells us that this was the fertile presence in these regions that are now sand today were abundant green ecosystems, right.

[1242.7s - 1254.2s]: And some curious, you know, what your thoughts are in terms of notwithstanding the challenges, what's really possible in the coming years, if our global community does respond in a way we hope to see.

[1255.1s - 1268.2s]: You know, our beneficiaries, you, this is hard to believe, planted over six billion trees around the world. And of course, Ethiopia, I don't know if you mean keeping what Ethiopia has been doing in planting trees.

[1268.2s - 1279.2s]: And I've met with the Prime Minister there are many occasions talking about it. Of course, they got some issues there on Tigray right now is another story, but there's so much that can be done and should be done.

[1279.9s - 1291.8s]: And here's how, you know, we support about a hundred million beneficiaries in our view and I find the beneficiaries, what can we do with the beneficiaries to help rehabilitate land because they want to do it.

[1291.8s - 1302.7s]: Let me give an example of what we just did in Afghanistan. In Afghanistan's struggling big time right now, famine is knocking on the door for a lot of people there, millions of people there.

[1303.2s - 1315.0s]: So historically, we would just bring in the food right and hand it out. Well, you can't grow certain types of grains everywhere in any given country, right. I mean, that's his common sense.

[1315.0s - 1327.4s]: And so in the Mausoleil Shereef area, which tough area, the mountainous area, flash floods and droughts. So we came in and said, all right, we've been bringing in this food from outside primarily the United States.

[1327.9s - 1335.0s]: So we met with the farmers on the other side of the country said, hey, the same amount of money, we go come in and buy from you.

[1335.0s - 1348.8s]: So we go prime the pump, help stimulate the local agricultural economy. And so we met with the farmers and the millers. They hired more people, hired more workers, bought more trucks and tractors and things like that.

[1349.5s - 1364.3s]: And we bought all the grain locally. Then we took the grain over to Mausoleil Shereef and said, all right, we'll give this to you. But let's rehabilitate where the mountains hit the valley.

[1364.7s - 1381.9s]: And because when the flash flood hits, it just flash floods and just wipes out any crops in the valley. Or if you have a drought, you don't have any water. So we began re-landscaping, coming down to the mountain side, having water reservoirs, unhoding dams, things of that.

[1382.6s - 1392.5s]: And then so when you had the flash flood, the water is contained. When you have the drought, we had to water reservoirs because then we did irrigation lines down into the valley.

[1392.5s - 1405.2s]: And so total success story. And I was asking the tribal leader, standing at the top by one of the dams, looking over the valley. And I said, what's the difference now?

[1406.5s - 1422.6s]: Aaron, he looked at me and said, before our children were leaving. They were leaving the country. They were joining anti-government rebel forces. They saw no hope, no opportunity.

[1422.6s - 1434.1s]: He said, I said to what about now? He says, this is just totally brought life back to the community. So we're talking about the basic, the fundamentals of bringing life to a community.

[1434.6s - 1445.7s]: We're using the soil, rehabilitating it, protecting it, and all the things that we need to do going forward. And so there's a lot that needs to be done. We have a lot to learn from one another.

[1445.7s - 1457.2s]: I think there's a lot we can learn from some of the things that you're doing while on earth and what can you learn from us? What types of things are scalable and what types of areas?

[1457.8s - 1469.0s]: There's so much to be understood, so much to learn. You know, down in Southern Africa, you know, as the temperature continues to rise, we know for every degree of temperature you have a reduction in amount of maize.

[1469.0s - 1480.8s]: Well, maize wasn't natural. Consume down there 100 years ago was brought in from the outsiders as a carbohydrate. Well, their products, much more nutritious, and much more resilient to heat.

[1481.3s - 1490.6s]: So we want to take advantage of these bad scenarios to change old habits that really are not nutritious as far families in the culture.

[1490.6s - 1500.9s]: And so a lot of little things with a calamity. Let's take advantage of it to try to do improve practices and better behavior. So that's just our obligation to do so.

[1502.2s - 1518.4s]: Absolutely, absolutely. David. And so I know you're on a very busy schedule today and appreciate you taking time to visit with us. And you know, I want to ask specifically for our American audience here through the Y on earth community.

[1518.4s - 1530.7s]: What is the call to action you would encourage, you know, regular folks here in this country to do to help the work you're doing with your team there at the World Food Program?

[1531.4s - 1540.8s]: Well, there's several things. Number one, and first and foremost, look to your neighbors in your own community. You might be surprised who needs help.

[1540.8s - 1553.0s]: You really might be be willing to drive across the railroad tracks and see what's happening. And you'll end up being touched more so than those indeed. I can assure you that.

[1553.6s - 1565.4s]: And so please look out for those struggling in your own area. Number two is yes, don't hesitate to speak out to your political leaders about supporting international a strategic international a I think that's very important.

[1566.5s - 1577.4s]: You know, our operations so big people said, well, gosh, you know, you need billions. What can I do there? I'm like, you know, we feed a child for about 25 cents.

[1577.4s - 1595.4s]: If you just send a dollar, you can go to www.sharethemeal.org, www.sharethemeal.org, and pick a country and we are extremely efficient operation.

[1595.4s - 1611.3s]: Whether it's $5, $10, $1, it will make a difference and believe you me, I was doing a TV show not long ago. And I don't remember, you might remember Scott Pelley with 60 minutes.

[1611.3s - 1620.7s]: It was a tough story. We were doing on Yemen, very bad situation. It is a very bad situation. I'm heading there literally in just a day or two.

[1622.8s - 1633.4s]: And we were wrapping down and Scott was taking off the mic and the camera was off. And Scott said, he said, Governor, you've got the greatest job in the world.

[1634.2s - 1642.7s]: Saving lives around the world. And I said, Scott, I really do. I said, but I'm going to say something to you that you hadn't thought about. And it's going to bother you.

[1642.8s - 1649.5s]: And he looked at me like, what in the world? I said, Scott, I don't go to bed at night thinking about the children we saved.

[1650.8s - 1667.7s]: I said, I go to bed worried weeping over children we couldn't save. And when we don't have enough money, I said, I hate to save this, but we have to choose which children eat and which children don't eat, which children live, which children die.

[1667.7s - 1675.0s]: I said, how would you like that job? And Scott was just mortified and like, oh my god, I've never thought about that. And I said, Scott, we don't have a choice.

[1675.0s - 1692.4s]: And when there's $400 trillion worth of wealth on Earth a day, and billionaires made $5.2 billion net worth increase during COVID. And I'm struggling just to get $5 billion to avert famine is shame on humanity is a disgrace.

[1693.4s - 1702.4s]: So please be engaged. Don't hesitate to give a dollar or $5, but please look out for the people in your own community.

[1702.9s - 1715.4s]: Stay up to date. Go to our website, which is, you know, you know, world food program. You just Google search it or whatever search mechanism you use. And you'll be surprised what's happening around the world and how our teams are out there.

[1715.7s - 1724.7s]: It's just like a wild earth, you know, you know, I don't get some of your stuff and I'll go to reading them like, oh, this is great stuff. And then I got to, you know, I'm about to get on a plane and I want to read it.

[1724.9s - 1734.4s]: And there's a lot of great stuff out there, a lot of great people, you know, I'm a, I'm a, the sun is rising kind of guy. I'm not the glasses half empty. I'm an optimist.

[1734.4s - 1747.4s]: This is going to be a difficult year. And I have people say, how do you, how do you keep optimistic? I said, well, when I'm out there and I see those little children, I mean in the rubble of the war zone.

[1747.7s - 1763.1s]: When you think there's no way they can have any smile or hope at all. You see what life is all about. They have the spirit of hope. And it just inspires you not to give up on one single child because we're all brothers and sisters.

[1763.1s - 1772.8s]: And we have an obligation to love our neighbor as our equal. And that's what we operate on. So Aaron, thank you, man. It's great being with you.

[1773.5s - 1782.7s]: Director Beasley, thank you. And thank you so much for taking the time to visit with us. And once again, congratulations on receiving the Nobel Peace Prize.

[1783.8s - 1787.9s]: And congratulations on all the great work you're doing out there.

[1788.5s - 1799.4s]: Well, thank you. Let's do it again sometime and let's make certain that our people kind of cross pollinate on the different things that you're doing that we're doing that we can learn from one another and help others.

[1801.1s - 1804.1s]: Absolutely. Look forward to it. Look forward to falling up with you on all that.

[1804.6s - 1805.6s]: You got it. Thanks.

[1805.6s - 1806.8s]: Thank you.

[1806.8s - 1821.9s]: All right. Take care. Bye bye. I hope you enjoyed this episode and took away the critical importance that we all get further involved in helping to deal with the challenging situations that we're facing all around the world.

[1821.9s - 1841.9s]: And especially if in our own lives, we've got some semblance of stability and security. It is critical that we each do our part to help our brothers and sisters in other parts of the world, or even in our own communities as David suggested, who are struggling with less security and stability.

[1843.1s - 1859.8s]: I'd like to take a moment to give a shout out to many of our partners and supporters who make this podcast series possible and who are also supporting our community mobilization efforts for climate action, soil regeneration, neighborhood resilience and a culture of kindness.

[1859.8s - 1879.6s]: This includes Earth Coast productions, the Lidge Family Foundation, Alpine Botanicals, Purium, Earth Hero, Liquid Trainer, Vera Herbels, Growing Spaces, Soil Works, Earthwater Press, 1% for the planet, Dr. Bronners and Walei Waters.

[1880.6s - 1894.3s]: You can get discounts on many of the products and services from these companies by going to Y-North.org, slash partners, dash supporters, or find the page under our community section.

[1895.6s - 1910.7s]: If you would like to join our monthly support program as an individual, and join many others who are making monthly donations to the Y-North community, you can do so by going to Y-North.org slash support.

[1910.7s - 1926.3s]: You can sign up at any level that works for you, and if you sign up at the $33 a month or greater level, we will send you monthly shipments of biodynamically grown hemp infused aroma therapy soaking salts made by Walei Waters.

[1927.0s - 1938.2s]: A huge shout out to all of the people who have already joined our monthly support program and to these companies who are part of our ecosystem of regeneration and stewardship.

[1939.3s - 1947.1s]: Thank you for getting involved. Thank you for doing your part in the community, and thank you for tuning in to the Y-North community podcast.

[1947.9s - 1957.6s]: The Y-North community stewardship and sustainability podcast series is hosted by Aaron William Perry, author, thought leader, and executive consultant.

[1958.5s - 1963.4s]: The podcast and video recordings are made possible by the generous support of people like you.

[1963.4s - 1971.1s]: To sign up as a daily, weekly, or monthly supporter, please visit Y-North.org-sport.

[1971.9s - 1974.8s]: Support packages start at just $1 per month.

[1975.8s - 1980.9s]: The podcast series is also sponsored by several corporate and organization sponsors.

[1981.5s - 1988.7s]: You can get discounts on their products and services using the code Y-On-Earth, all one word with a Y.

[1989.5s - 1994.7s]: These sponsors are listed on the Y-On-Earth.org-sport.org page.

[1995.2s - 2005.0s]: If you found this particular podcast episode especially insightful, informative, or inspiring, please pass it on and share it with a friend who you think will also enjoy it.

[2006.0s - 2013.2s]: Thank you for tuning in. Thank you for your support, and thank you for being a part of the Y-On-Earth community.

segments.text: Welcome to the Y on Earth community podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry. And today we have a very special episode with David Beasley, the executive director of the United Nations World Food Program, which was the recipient of the 2020 Nobel Peace Prize.

The World Food Program is at the heart of the convergence of several global challenges with COVID, the economic impacts, climate change, environmental degradation, and political instability in communities throughout the world.

The World Food Program is often the first and last line of defense for millions of people on the verge of starvation. You'll hear from David about not only the work they're doing right now to deal with these immediate crises for millions of our brothers and sisters around the world, but also the work that they're doing globally to help restore ecosystems and regenerate the foundations upon which our communities depend.

As executive director of the World Food Program, David Beasley continues his life's work bridging political, religious, and ethnic boundaries to champion economic development and education. At WFP, Mr. Beasley is putting to use four decades of leadership and communication skills to mobilize more financial support and public awareness for the global fight against hunger.

These efforts were recognized this year when the Norwegian Nobel Committee awarded the World Food Program the 2020 Nobel Peace Prize. Before coming to WFP in 2017, Mr. Beasley spent a decade working with high profile leaders and on the ground program managers in more than 100 countries directing projects designed to foster peace, reconciliation, and economic progress.

As governor of the US State of South Carolina from 1995 to 1999, Mr. Beasley guided the state during years of economic transformation, helping to reshape the state's economy into a healthy, diverse, and robust market. Mr. Beasley earned the John F. Kennedy Profile Encourage Award.
He received his bachelor's degree from Clemson University and a doctor of jurisprudence degree from the University of South Carolina and taught at the Harvard University Kennedy School of Government.
He was first elected to public office at the age of 21 as a member of the South Carolina House of Representatives. Without further ado, here's David Beasley.
Director Beasley, welcome to the show.
It's great to be with you. It's been quite a while and we got some really important and good things to talk about.
Yeah, we sure do. And as the executive director of the World Food Program, you are, first of all, let me just say congratulations on receiving the Nobel Peace Prize just a couple of months ago.
That's just a tremendous recognition of the work you and your team are already doing, but I think also it's going to help bring more awareness to the important issues you all are tackling.
So congratulations. Can you tell us what is it like to get that phone call?
Well, you don't get that phone call every day. I can just argue with that.
If we had known that we were going to get it, we probably would have choreographed this really fancy setting with a suit and all these inspired words.
As it was, I literally was in the middle of knees, and we were in a very tense situation. We were negotiating access.

I'd just come back from the field where we're trying to get access in the area where I had al-Qaeda on one side and ISIS on the other side because these extremist groups use access as a weapon for recruitment by the private people of food.
So it was a pretty intense discussion and all of a sudden somebody blessed into the room.
And I'm like, what the heck?
And this person said, Nobel Peace Prize. I was like, oh wow, who won it?
They said, we did. You did. The World Blue Program did. And I was like, you got to be kidding me.
Wow. I mean, it really was a surprise.
And I think, you know, Aaron, as you were saying, it was two things I think the Nobel Peace Prize Committee was doing.

The first, I think they were saying, hey, World Food Program, you're 20,000 women and men that are out there putting their lives on the line, lives at risk in war zones, conflict areas, natural disasters.
Thank you for bringing peace and stability to many, many places around the world.
So that was number one, you know, as a model for the, for others around the world.
Number two, it, I think it was a call to action because I believe the Nobel Peace Prize Committee saw exactly what we were seeing.
While 2020 was a tough year, 2021 is going to even be more difficult because of the COVID economic ripple effect, the supply chain disruption.

And when I say supply chain disruption, that is a comprehensive comment because we're talking about port, port shuts down, border crossing shutdowns, export ban, seeds, fertilizers, all these things that are critical to many of the developing nations around the world.
So we, in the World Food Program, our needs because of the ripple effect are double.
The number of people that literally are marching to the Branker Starvation, I'm not talking about people that just go to bit hungry.
I'm talking about people that are marching to starvation.
That number spiked from 135 to 270 million people.
So our needs, financial needs have doubled.
And we can talk about this more in detail in a little bit.
But 2021 is going to be a very, very difficult year.
Let me just mention right there that for folks who would like to get even more information about the World Food Program, they can go to wfp.org.
David, I'm wondering, are you sensing that the national leaderships of the member nations around the world understand the magnitude of the problems and risks?
And are they responding in a way that you're encouraged is you in terms of resources?
Well, in 2020 they did.

And early on with COVID, a lot of the leaders were making decisions about COVID sort of in the vacuum, not understanding the ripple effect that it was taking and shutting down economies and particularly in light, very poor, undeveloped nations and urban areas when you shut down a city and have a lockdown.
It's not like in the United States, for example, the people, if you have a lockdown for two weeks, three weeks, you got food in your pantry for two to three weeks.
You might not like what you eat on the third week, but you go be okay.
Well, where we are, it's hand to mouth every day. There's not a pantry full of food.
So if you have a lockdown, you've got to have a safety net program in place.
And so what I did, and if I recall correctly, it was about two weeks before I was speaking to the United Nations Security Council about the travesty that we were looking at.
And Tony Blair called me and he said, David, you are more places around the world than about anybody.
What are you seeing out there? And I said, Tony, I'm afraid if we're not careful, the cure is going to be worse than the disease.
And so we've got to really balance the health pandemic, COVID pandemic, with a health with a hunger pandemic.
If we don't, it will have catastrophic consequences.
And so I broke it down with Tony for about a half a dozen countries.
What we were seeing over the next four to five quarters.
And the economic dynamics in each of the countries and how it has a different effect.
And Tony was like, oh my gosh, you've got to tell the world what you're seeing.
And so I did. I went to the Security Council, gave them the very grave reality, what we were facing.
And the world leaders stepped up in a very significant way.
You had economic stimulus packages about $19 trillion in the year 2020.
But there was debt deferral for low-income countries that would take their debt payment.
Instead of sending it to the financial institutions, they used that for safety net programs to get through 2020.
And I could go on and on and on and all the good things that were done.
Because what happened in 2020, we didn't have famine, we didn't have destabilization, and we didn't have mass migration.
Because we received the funds that we needed.
We assisted about 100 million people in 2020.
But we were hoping that COVID would be in our rearview mirror in the 2021 would be a lighter path forward.
Unfortunately, that's not the case.
So we don't have all the money available for 2020 for 2021.
And now the needs are double. So here's what we're looking at with 270 million people.
If we don't receive sufficient funds to address the most significant concerns, we will have mass famines, destabilization of nations, and mass migration.
Now, if we don't do the things that we need to do, it's going to cost a thousand times more than getting on the front end and doing it right.
Now, I've been talking to the leaders all day to day over the last few months, you're going to have to prioritize your limited funding.
You can't say yet to everything in 2021.
And so I use the analogy, it's like the Titanic head and toward icebergs.
You've got a broken piece of tile in the bathroom.
You've got a little bit of wine stain on the carpet and a broken wine glass in the bar.
But you've got three icebergs ahead of you.
Which one are you going to focus on? The icebergs are the small things.
I said, the icebergs are famine, destabilization, and mass migration.
Because if we don't, we'll have war, conflict, and that is a thousand times more impact than not doing so.
So I haven't had a leader yet, say they want to back down.
They understand it, they get it.
But the needs are so big.
We can't expect the governments alone to pick up the tab.
So that's why I'm now calling on the world's billionaires.
Because last year 2020, the world's wealthiest people, the billionaires, increase their net worth.
Net worth increase now by $5.2 billion per day per day for 2020.
And all I'm asking is to give me one day's worth of your net worth increase to avert famine.
I need five billion just to avert famine.
If I get that, then with my traditional government support and private safety support, then we should really have...
It will still be a tough 2021, but we'll get through it.
That's sort of where we are now, Eric.
Well, David, it's tremendous hearing from the central purview that you have the degree of systemic risk we're facing right now.
And I would argue that probably a whole lot of us in the general public aren't quite aware of just how much more difficult challenging it.
And really devastating things could get in relatively short order here.
Well, you know, and this is what I've been saying, because when you turn on the television the last four years, I mean, what was 90% of the news?
It was Trump, Trump, Trump, Trump.
Whether you loved or hated Trump or Brexit, Brexit, Brexit, Brexit.
And people were not getting the information about destabilization and hurricanes and natural disasters, climate extremes, et cetera, et cetera, around the world.
And we're out there all hands on deck, you know, every single day dealing with this.
And so we see the reality and we see what's taking place over a longer-stained time period, you know, like on climate extremes.
I've had some people say, well, I don't know about whether the climate's changing.

And I said, look, you can debate all day long what's causing it to change, but I can tell you what you can't debate, because I'm out there first hand with my people seeing it what is happening in the Sahel and the world.
In Southern Africa, Asia, where the climate is truly changing from more droughts, more flash floods, more this, more of that.
And, you know, the poor people we're talking about in many of these places, they can't wait on a global solution.
They got to survive the next year, because they've got to feed their children.
They got to eat. They can't, you know, just jump in a car and drive somewhere.
I mean, they got to survive them. And I think, listen, you and I talk about some of the things that we're doing on regenerating and rehabilitating the lands and the soils.
Yeah, yeah. I'd love to hear that because I, you know, one of the things that strikes me, David, and, you know, even I met a few years back at a piece in reconciliation summit in Kosovo.
And we've been looking at different aspects of these issues that are all entwined in a very complex global community and global situation.

And it seems to me that especially given the potential degree of immediate crisis we're facing, and also knowing that a huge part of our solutions set going forward requires ecosystem and soil regeneration and restoration.
And that's part of how we're going to stabilize some of these very vulnerable regions in the world.
I'm curious to hear how you all at the World's Food Program are thinking about how to both tackle the immediate crises and potential crises and also help with the long term stabilization.

You know, unfortunately, because we're facing so many fires this year, it's like put out the fires, put out the fires, you'll be like, you know, you're one of your children comes in and say, Dad, I want to talk about my new cow.
And I'm like, you know, I like to talk about that, but I got four house fires right now. Let's just talk about that later.
But on the long term perspective, if we don't deal with the issue that you were just raising, we're going to have calamity decades ahead of us.
The population of the world is continuing to go up, of course, we're at 7.7 billion.
We've done a lot of extraordinary successful things around the world in the last couple of hundred years, sharing more wealth and people getting more food.
But it's not sustainable in the way we're going. So what can we do?

You know, particularly in some of the areas that we are in, let's take Niger, Mali, Burkina Faso, the Sahel, you know, as the Sahara is moving down about a kilometer per year because of the lack of rain, etc., etc.
And so in areas like this, when our old traditional approach was just bringing food and support people, well, you know, that's not changing anything.
So we began working with the beneficiaries and let me say this, I hadn't found the beneficiary yet that said, I want to do nothing and sit around just get your food.
I haven't met that person yet. They want to be independent. They want to be resilient. They want to be sustainable without outside support.
And so we now come in and say, hey, we've got the food. We go work with you. And sometimes it may be a task. It depends on the modality that we need the most strategic and what reason.
And so let's rehabilitate the land. And so we will do an area is like, you know, if you do pull up photos in the Sahel, I mean, it's pretty tough place.

If you go to these places, you're like, how in the world can you survive? Well, we do basic, I mean rudimentary basic agricultural practices of training and teaching half moon, side projects where we capture the limited water that comes.
And so you don't have the flash flooding, capture the water, grows enough crops to survive. Now, we, I say we, I mean, I've been a fisheries.
In the last four or five years of rehabilitated 3.5 million acres of land, 70, let's say 73, 75,000 kilometers of feeder roads for marketplace.
It's hard to understand that in the Western community, but in a lot of these places, there aren't roads, you know, they're just not. And then I think 53,000 holding ponds, water reservoirs, wells.
And our beneficiaries love it because they're out there. I had this one woman. She said, Mr. Beasley, this is a Nigerian. She said, she was standing on this hill and she stood with so much pride.

She said, before we were dependent on you 100%. Now we've rehabilitated this land. I own five acres. I'm now not only feeding my family, I'm feeding my village. I'm buying five more acres and I'm going to sell to the marketplace.
And it was just remarkable using just a basic of agricultural practices of taking the land and what she had to survive for her family and her children.

Now, it's amazing that these are the people that pay the price for carbon consumption. And there was this doing more to rehabilitate and regenerate lands around the world. That's really kind of extraordinary. I'm so proud of them.

And that's just some ideas of some of the things we do a lot of hydroponics on different places around the world. We're testing a lot of things. And of course, that's in the most difficult places on earth, like in Algeria and places where it's very dry.
Now, hydroponics has a lot as you know, opportunities in urban areas and things like that. And we do a lot of also of artificial intelligence and hydro blockchain technology satellite imagery.

We're doing a lot of different things, a lot of different patterns, but we also do a lot of composting. I was just in knee, I think it was knee share of bikina fossa where we've got women doing composting and not just for their village, but they're now selling that throughout the land from composting and a lot of things like that. But anyway, throw it back to you, Aaron.

That's great to hear, David. And obviously all tools and technologies need to be deployed in smart manners here given the challenges that we're facing. And one of the things that has struck me over the last few years in the research that we've been doing at the wider community is that a 10% increase in soil carbon worldwide is equivalent to sequestering all of the fossil carbon we've released since the beginning of the year.

And so it's the beginning of the industrial revolution. And you know, folks like John Lou, one of our recent guests, the founder of ecosystem restoration camps, who was very close to the project there at the Los Plateau in China, where they literally restored hundreds of thousands of acres of desert and brought hundreds of thousands of people out of extreme poverty.

There's a way here we can not only help increase food security and sustainable economic development for communities in a lot of marginalized regions, but also restore the green fertility of the planet and stabilize the climate.

And I'm struck that in North Africa, Middle East, you know, these are some of the most desertified and challenging places in the world. And our tradition tells us that this was the fertile presence in these regions that are now sand today were abundant green ecosystems, right.

And some curious, you know, what your thoughts are in terms of notwithstanding the challenges, what's really possible in the coming years, if our global community does respond in a way we hope to see.

You know, our beneficiaries, you, this is hard to believe, planted over six billion trees around the world. And of course, Ethiopia, I don't know if you mean keeping what Ethiopia has been doing in planting trees.

And I've met with the Prime Minister there are many occasions talking about it. Of course, they got some issues there on Tigray right now is another story, but there's so much that can be done and should be done.

And here's how, you know, we support about a hundred million beneficiaries in our view and I find the beneficiaries, what can we do with the beneficiaries to help rehabilitate land because they want to do it.
Let me give an example of what we just did in Afghanistan. In Afghanistan's struggling big time right now, famine is knocking on the door for a lot of people there, millions of people there.
So historically, we would just bring in the food right and hand it out. Well, you can't grow certain types of grains everywhere in any given country, right. I mean, that's his common sense.

And so in the Mausoleil Shereef area, which tough area, the mountainous area, flash floods and droughts. So we came in and said, all right, we've been bringing in this food from outside primarily the United States.
So we met with the farmers on the other side of the country said, hey, the same amount of money, we go come in and buy from you.

So we go prime the pump, help stimulate the local agricultural economy. And so we met with the farmers and the millers. They hired more people, hired more workers, bought more trucks and tractors and things like that.
And we bought all the grain locally. Then we took the grain over to Mausoleil Shereef and said, all right, we'll give this to you. But let's rehabilitate where the mountains hit the valley.

And because when the flash flood hits, it just flash floods and just wipes out any crops in the valley. Or if you have a drought, you don't have any water. So we began re-landscaping, coming down to the mountain side, having water reservoirs, unhoding dams, things of that.
And then so when you had the flash flood, the water is contained. When you have the drought, we had to water reservoirs because then we did irrigation lines down into the valley.
And so total success story. And I was asking the tribal leader, standing at the top by one of the dams, looking over the valley. And I said, what's the difference now?
Aaron, he looked at me and said, before our children were leaving. They were leaving the country. They were joining anti-government rebel forces. They saw no hope, no opportunity.
He said, I said to what about now? He says, this is just totally brought life back to the community. So we're talking about the basic, the fundamentals of bringing life to a community.
We're using the soil, rehabilitating it, protecting it, and all the things that we need to do going forward. And so there's a lot that needs to be done. We have a lot to learn from one another.
I think there's a lot we can learn from some of the things that you're doing while on earth and what can you learn from us? What types of things are scalable and what types of areas?

There's so much to be understood, so much to learn. You know, down in Southern Africa, you know, as the temperature continues to rise, we know for every degree of temperature you have a reduction in amount of maize.
Well, maize wasn't natural. Consume down there 100 years ago was brought in from the outsiders as a carbohydrate. Well, their products, much more nutritious, and much more resilient to heat.
So we want to take advantage of these bad scenarios to change old habits that really are not nutritious as far families in the culture.
And so a lot of little things with a calamity. Let's take advantage of it to try to do improve practices and better behavior. So that's just our obligation to do so.

Absolutely, absolutely. David. And so I know you're on a very busy schedule today and appreciate you taking time to visit with us. And you know, I want to ask specifically for our American audience here through the Y on earth community.
What is the call to action you would encourage, you know, regular folks here in this country to do to help the work you're doing with your team there at the World Food Program?
Well, there's several things. Number one, and first and foremost, look to your neighbors in your own community. You might be surprised who needs help.
You really might be be willing to drive across the railroad tracks and see what's happening. And you'll end up being touched more so than those indeed. I can assure you that.

And so please look out for those struggling in your own area. Number two is yes, don't hesitate to speak out to your political leaders about supporting international a strategic international a I think that's very important.
You know, our operations so big people said, well, gosh, you know, you need billions. What can I do there? I'm like, you know, we feed a child for about 25 cents.
If you just send a dollar, you can go to www.sharethemeal.org, www.sharethemeal.org, and pick a country and we are extremely efficient operation.
Whether it's $5, $10, $1, it will make a difference and believe you me, I was doing a TV show not long ago. And I don't remember, you might remember Scott Pelley with 60 minutes.
It was a tough story. We were doing on Yemen, very bad situation. It is a very bad situation. I'm heading there literally in just a day or two.
And we were wrapping down and Scott was taking off the mic and the camera was off. And Scott said, he said, Governor, you've got the greatest job in the world.
Saving lives around the world. And I said, Scott, I really do. I said, but I'm going to say something to you that you hadn't thought about. And it's going to bother you.
And he looked at me like, what in the world? I said, Scott, I don't go to bed at night thinking about the children we saved.

I said, I go to bed worried weeping over children we couldn't save. And when we don't have enough money, I said, I hate to save this, but we have to choose which children eat and which children don't eat, which children live, which children die.
I said, how would you like that job? And Scott was just mortified and like, oh my god, I've never thought about that. And I said, Scott, we don't have a choice.

And when there's $400 trillion worth of wealth on Earth a day, and billionaires made $5.2 billion net worth increase during COVID. And I'm struggling just to get $5 billion to avert famine is shame on humanity is a disgrace.
So please be engaged. Don't hesitate to give a dollar or $5, but please look out for the people in your own community.

Stay up to date. Go to our website, which is, you know, you know, world food program. You just Google search it or whatever search mechanism you use. And you'll be surprised what's happening around the world and how our teams are out there.

It's just like a wild earth, you know, you know, I don't get some of your stuff and I'll go to reading them like, oh, this is great stuff. And then I got to, you know, I'm about to get on a plane and I want to read it.
And there's a lot of great stuff out there, a lot of great people, you know, I'm a, I'm a, the sun is rising kind of guy. I'm not the glasses half empty. I'm an optimist.

This is going to be a difficult year. And I have people say, how do you, how do you keep optimistic? I said, well, when I'm out there and I see those little children, I mean in the rubble of the war zone.

When you think there's no way they can have any smile or hope at all. You see what life is all about. They have the spirit of hope. And it just inspires you not to give up on one single child because we're all brothers and sisters.
And we have an obligation to love our neighbor as our equal. And that's what we operate on. So Aaron, thank you, man. It's great being with you.
Director Beasley, thank you. And thank you so much for taking the time to visit with us. And once again, congratulations on receiving the Nobel Peace Prize.
And congratulations on all the great work you're doing out there.

Well, thank you. Let's do it again sometime and let's make certain that our people kind of cross pollinate on the different things that you're doing that we're doing that we can learn from one another and help others.
Absolutely. Look forward to it. Look forward to falling up with you on all that.
You got it. Thanks.
Thank you.

All right. Take care. Bye bye. I hope you enjoyed this episode and took away the critical importance that we all get further involved in helping to deal with the challenging situations that we're facing all around the world.

And especially if in our own lives, we've got some semblance of stability and security. It is critical that we each do our part to help our brothers and sisters in other parts of the world, or even in our own communities as David suggested, who are struggling with less security and stability.

I'd like to take a moment to give a shout out to many of our partners and supporters who make this podcast series possible and who are also supporting our community mobilization efforts for climate action, soil regeneration, neighborhood resilience and a culture of kindness.

This includes Earth Coast productions, the Lidge Family Foundation, Alpine Botanicals, Purium, Earth Hero, Liquid Trainer, Vera Herbels, Growing Spaces, Soil Works, Earthwater Press, 1% for the planet, Dr. Bronners and Walei Waters.
You can get discounts on many of the products and services from these companies by going to Y-North.org, slash partners, dash supporters, or find the page under our community section.

If you would like to join our monthly support program as an individual, and join many others who are making monthly donations to the Y-North community, you can do so by going to Y-North.org slash support.

You can sign up at any level that works for you, and if you sign up at the $33 a month or greater level, we will send you monthly shipments of biodynamically grown hemp infused aroma therapy soaking salts made by Walei Waters.
A huge shout out to all of the people who have already joined our monthly support program and to these companies who are part of our ecosystem of regeneration and stewardship.
Thank you for getting involved. Thank you for doing your part in the community, and thank you for tuning in to the Y-North community podcast.
The Y-North community stewardship and sustainability podcast series is hosted by Aaron William Perry, author, thought leader, and executive consultant.
The podcast and video recordings are made possible by the generous support of people like you.
To sign up as a daily, weekly, or monthly supporter, please visit Y-North.org-sport.
Support packages start at just $1 per month.
The podcast series is also sponsored by several corporate and organization sponsors.
You can get discounts on their products and services using the code Y-On-Earth, all one word with a Y.
These sponsors are listed on the Y-On-Earth.org-sport.org page.
If you found this particular podcast episode especially insightful, informative, or inspiring, please pass it on and share it with a friend who you think will also enjoy it.
Thank you for tuning in. Thank you for your support, and thank you for being a part of the Y-On-Earth community.
